Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF), coronary artery disease (CAD), and atrial fibrillation. He presents from a rehabilitation facility with respiratory distress. The patient has been diagnosed with several medical conditions, including respiratory failure, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, bacterial community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), acute renal failure (ARF), atrial fibrillation (AFib), type II diabetes mellitus (DM), urinary tract infection (UTI), and acute on chronic diastolic heart failure (CHF).

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 36.2Â°C, heart rate of 99 beats per minute, blood pressure of 128/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's lab results show an elevated white blood cell count of 5.6 K/uL, decreased hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, increased lactate level of 29.6%, and elevated troponin-T level of 0.12 ng/mL.

The patient has been placed on various treatments and interventions, including aggressive volume resuscitation, diuresis to facilitate weaning off the ventilator, beta-blockers for improved rate control and prevention of further cardiac complications, continuation of current antibiotics, Foley catheterization to monitor urine

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure (CHF), coronary artery disease (CAD), and atrial fibrillation presenting from a rehabilitation facility with respiratory distress. The patient's medical conditions include respiratory failure, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, community-acquired bacterial pneumonia, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, type II diabetes mellitus, urinary tract infection, acute-on-chronic diastolic heart failure, and acute myocardial infarction.

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 36.2 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 99 beats per minute, blood pressure of 128/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is intubated and receiving invasive ventilation with a tidal volume of 450 mL, respiratory system compliance of 35, peak inspiratory pressure of 15 cmH2O, plateau pressure of 14 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 5.6 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, blood glucose of 92 mg/dL, sodium of 116 mEq/L, potassium of 4.5 mEq/L, creatinine of 0.6 mg/dL, and platelet count of 343 K/uL.

   Assessment and Plan
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
   Pt currently in septic shock. Currently on sepsis protocol. Has had 5L
   of NS thus far. Also on pressors. Will start dobumatine as cardiac
   functioning impaired. No urgent indication for PA catheter at this
   time. Goal MAP > 65, SvO2 > 70%, glucose 80-150. Will treat for
   suspected pulmonary and urinary source with vancomycin, meropenem, and
   azithromycin. Urgent A-line placement. Cortisol simulation but will
   empirically treat with steroids given clinical history and recent
   therapy with Megace. Will give one dose of dexamethasone now while
   awaiting cortisol level. Transfuse 1 unit of blood, goal HCT 30. BCx
   pending, will obtain UCx, U/A grossly positive. Will send influenza,
   c.diff, and sputum culture. CXR with evidence of B/L infiltrates, once
   ABG and assessment of oxygenation, may need to switch to ARDS net
   protocol for ventilation.
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   Most likely [**3-5**] to PNA/septic shock. Also concern for cardiogenic shock
   given pt
s longstanding cardiac disease and intravascular depletion.
   Wean FiO2 as tolerated. STAT ABG and placement of A-line. Consider ARDS
   net ventilation if difficulty with oxygenation. ABx regimen vancomycin
   (IV for HAP, PO for c.diff), meropenem, azithromycin. Will send sputum
   and respiratory cultures.
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
   Baseline 0.7, currenly 1.1. Renal dose meds, dose vancomycin by level.
   Aggressive IVF resustitation. Goal urine output at least 30 mL/hour.
   Will send urine lytes and UCx.
 PNEUMONIA, BACTERIAL, COMMUNITY ACQUIRED (CAP)
   Cover broadly given patient frequently in hospital and rehab.
   Vancomycin, meropenem, and azithromycin. Will send sputum culture and
   respiratory cultures.
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
   Hold antihypertensives for now given septic shock. Monitor HR. Continue
   ASA and Plavix.
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
   Insulin gtt given need for tight glycemic control in the setting of
   septic shock.
 URINARY TRACT INFECTION (UTI)
   Cover with meropenem given h/o ESBL. Will send UCx.
 HEART FAILURE (CHF), DIASTOLIC, ACUTE ON CHRONIC
   Will start dobutamine given cardiac dysfunction in setting of septic
   shock. Repeat TTE today. Continue ASA and Plavix. BNP extremely
   elevated.
   ANEMIA
   Transfuse to keep HCT 30.
   ICU Care

The patient has been diagnosed with severe sepsis with organ dysfunction and is currently in septic shock. He is on pressors and receiving fluid resuscitation. 

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.2Â°C, heart rate of 99 bpm, blood pressure of 128/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. 

The patient has been placed on invasive ventilation and has an arterial line, presep catheter, and central venous pressure (CVP) monitoring. 

Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 16,000 cells/mmÂ³, elevated lactate level of 2.3 mmol/L, and signs of renal dysfunction with an elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 29.6 mg/dL and creatinine level of 0.6 mg/dL. 

Chest X-ray shows evidence of bilateral infiltrates, suggesting possible pneumonia. Urine culture is positive, indicating a urinary tract infection (UTI). 

The patient is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics including vancomycin, meropenem, and azithromycin. He is also receiving dobutamine for cardiac

5. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's renal function is compromised, and there is a risk of further deterioration leading to chronic kidney disease.

Summary:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and congestive heart failure (CHF). He was admitted to the hospital with respiratory distress and has been in the ICU since then.

The patient's recent events include being rate controlled and diuresed, but failing a spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) yesterday. A viral panel came back positive for influenza B, and he has been started on tamiflu. There is also a question about a clot removed from his urethra. Additionally, the patient has a dislocated left shoulder, and imaging will be repeated when he is more stable. Due to sedation, the patient is unable to provide a medical history.

The patient's allergies include Bactrim (oral) with a rash and Remeron with an unknown reaction. His last dose of antibiotics was Azithromycin 500mg IV daily on day 3, Meropenem 500mg IV q6h daily 3, and Vancomycin 1g IV daily on day 3. The patient is currently receiving infusions of Fentanyl at 50 mcg/hour and Midazolam (Versed) at 2 mg/hour. His other medications include ASA 81 daily, Plavix 37.5 daily, Heparin SQ, Insulin SQ, Levothyroxine, Protonix

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and congestive heart failure (CHF). He was admitted with respiratory distress and has been diagnosed with influenza B. The patient has had several medical complications including a clot in his urethra, dislocated left shoulder, decreased ejection fraction (EF), and acute renal failure (ARF). He is currently on mechanical ventilation and has been treated with antibiotics, sedatives, and pain medications. The patient's vital signs are stable, but he remains sedated and unable to provide a history. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Pneumonia: The patient has a positive viral panel for influenza B and shows signs of pulmonary edema on the chest X-ray. It is important to continue current antibiotics and monitor for any changes in respiratory status.
2. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his bacterial pneumonia and positive blood cultures. Close monitoring of vital signs, urine output, and laboratory values is necessary.
3. Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating acute renal failure. Continued monitoring of renal function and adjustment of fluid and electrolyte management are needed.
4. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which can contribute to poor rate control and further complications. Beta-blockers should be resumed as tolerated.
5. Diabetes Mellitus

   Oxygenation improved today, good RSBI
 but failed SBT yesterday
   secondary to hypoxia. Will wean to PSV today and reassess respiratory
   status later today for consideration of repeat SBT. Will continue
   diuresis to goal negative 1-2liters, increase rate control with
   titration up of metoprolol. Will continue vancomycin now pending sputum
   culture results as patient at risk for staph superinfection in setting
   of influenza. Given elevated vancomycin trough today will hold
   vancomycin today and repeat trough in AM, goal trough 15-20. Can D/C
   azithromycin.  Meropenem will be continued as well for UTI.
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)
   Doing well off of pressors. Most likely secondary to pneumonia. Goal
   MAP>65, follow urine output.
 Influenza
   Respiratory virus screen positive for influenza B antigen, cx pending.
   Day 2 of [**Last Name (LF) 1071**], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**] continue for 5 day course.
 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
   Cr slightly elevated from yesterday, making good amount s of urine.
   Follow for now.
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
   Patient on both diltiazem and metoprolol at home, neither of which at
   maximum dose, uncertain why patient on both of these. Increase
   metoprolol as above. Apparently not on anticoagulation at [**Hospital 1072**], but will review records
 in any case INR supratherapeutic at
   5.4 today.
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
   Continue SQ insulin with fingersticks, glucose under fair control, goal
   fingersticks<150.
 URINARY TRACT INFECTION (UTI)
   h/o ESBL E. coli and Klebsiella [**3-2**] urine, should be covered by
   meropenem. s/p ~7 day course gentamicin. Repeat urinalysis/culture.
 HEART FAILURE (CHF), DIASTOLIC, ACUTE ON CHRONIC
   EF depressed on TTE yesterday, suspect influenza related myocarditis.
   No evidence of new ischemic event as patient ruled out for MI by
   biomarkers. Can consider repeat TTE as outpatient to assess for
   recovery of pump function. Continue beta blockers, diuresis as above.
 Coagulopathy
   INR elevated at 5.4 today, with PTT stable, elevated ~45. Concern for
   DIC given recent sepsis, so will check fibrinogen, smear, FDP. Will
   give PO vitamin K and repeat coags in afternoon. Discontinue
   subcutaneous heparin.
 ANEMIA
   No evidence of active bleeding. Had normal iron studies [**2-8**], normal
   B12 and folate [**10-9**].
   Transfused yesterday per sepsis protocol to increase SVO2. Hct stable,
   no evidence of active bleeding. Transfuse Hb>7.
 Left shoulder dislocation, suspected
   Repeat shoulder imaging to better assess, follow up with ortho if
   needed
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:  NPO pending extubation
   Glycemic Control:  Regular insulin sliding scale

   Presep Catheter - [**2185-3-22**] 12:13 PM
   18 Gauge - [**2185-3-22**] 12:15 PM

   Stress ulcer: PPI
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Communication:  with family
   Code status: DNR (do not resuscitate)

He was admitted with respiratory distress and tested positive for influenza B. The patient had a clot removed from his urethra and a dislocated left shoulder, which could be manually relocated but dislocated again. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed decreased ejection fraction (EF). The patient is unable to provide history due to sedation. He has allergies to Bactrim and Remeron, and receives various medications including metoprolol, ASA, Plavix, heparin, insulin, and others. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for respiratory distress.

He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to respiratory distress from another hospital. The patient's condition has been unstable, with rate-controlled and diuresed but failed spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) yesterday. The viral panel came back positive for influenza B, and he has been started on tamiflu. There is also a question about a clot removed from the urethra. The patient has a dislocated left shoulder, which will be reimaged when more stable. Due to sedation, the patient is unable to provide any history.

The patient has multiple allergies, including Bactrim (oral) causing a rash and Remeron with an unknown reaction. The last doses of antibiotics given were meropenem, azithromycin, and vancomycin. The patient is currently on infusions of fentanyl and midazolam (versed), as well as other medications.

The review of systems remains unchanged from admission except for respiratory distress. The flowsheet data shows the patient's vital signs, including temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation. The patient is in atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. Hemodynamic monitoring indicates a central venous pressure (CVP) of 20 mmHg, cardiac output (CO)

   85M with influenza B, presenting with shock and hypoxic respiratory
   failure due to flu, pulmonary edema from global hypokinesis.
   # HYPOXIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Flu and pulmonary edema, possibly
   bacterial superinfection.
   -          Diurese 1-1.5L neg
   -          Continue Tamiflu, empiric abx
   -          Cardiac optimization
   -          Continue AC ventilation for now, increase VT to 500 from
   450. Consider PSV later in day following diuresis.
   # HEART FAILURE: Global HK likely due to viral infection/sepsis, afib
   with RVR
   -          Improve rate control with increasing doses of metoprolol
   -          Diuresis as above
   # COAGULOPATHY: Apparently not on coumadin at home. INR up > PTT.
   Differential includes malnutrition, DIC, acquired factor inhibitor or
   factor deficiency
   -          Will check DIC labs, follow coags and platelets, and give
   vitamin K
   # UTI: Urine cx with yeast, foley changed yesterday
   -          Continue current abx, follow cultures
   # ANEMIA: Chronic, iron deficient. Ferritin was 50 in [**Month (only) **].
   -          Continue to monitor HCT.
   # GENERAL ICU CARE: PPI, will place P-[**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**] start TFs today
   # CODE: DNR
Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old male with influenza B, presenting with shock and hypoxic respiratory failure due to flu, pulmonary edema from global hypokinesis. The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, severe sepsis, bacterial pneumonia, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, type II diabetes mellitus, urinary tract infection, and acute-on-chronic diastolic heart failure with a possible myocardial infarction.

The potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include worsening respiratory failure leading to ARDS, further deterioration of renal function, progression of sepsis and septic shock, development of complications related to atrial fibrillation such as stroke or heart rhythm disturbances, worsening of diabetes control, progression of urinary tract infection, and worsening of heart failure.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, oxygenation, renal function, blood glucose levels, and coagulation profile. Promptly addressing any changes in the patient's condition and adjusting the treatment plan accordingly is crucial. Additionally, the patient's code status of full code should be respected, and efforts should be made to optimize cardiac function, manage fluid balance, and prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia.

   -          Diurese 1-1.5L neg
   -          Continue Tamiflu, empiric abx
   -          Cardiac optimization
   -          Continue AC ventilation for now, increase VT to 500 from
   450. Consider PSV later in day following diuresis.
   # HEART FAILURE (systolic, acute): Global HK likely due to viral
   infection/sepsis, afib with RVR
   -          Improve rate control with increasing doses of metoprolol
   -          Diuresis as above
   # COAGULOPATHY: Apparently not on coumadin at home. INR up > PTT.
   Differential includes malnutrition, DIC, acquired factor inhibitor or
   factor deficiency
   -          Will check DIC labs, follow coags and platelets, and give
   vitamin K
   # UTI: Urine cx with yeast, foley changed yesterday
   -          Continue current abx, follow cultures
   # ANEMIA: Chronic, iron deficient. Ferritin was 50 in [**Month (only) **].
   -          Continue to monitor HCT.
   # GENERAL ICU CARE: PPI, will place P-[**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**] start TFs today
   # CODE: DNR
   Patient is critically ill.
   CC Time: 40 min

The patient is an 85-year-old man with influenza B, presenting with shock and hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza and pulmonary edema from new global hypokinesis. The patient has multiple medical complications including heart failure, coagulopathy, urinary tract infection, anemia, and general ICU care. The patient's current treatment plan includes diuresis, continuing Tamiflu and empiric antibiotics, cardiac optimization, and continuing assisted ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to influenza and pulmonary edema. If not managed appropriately, this can lead to further deterioration in oxygenation and potential cardiovascular collapse.
2. Heart failure: The patient's global hypokinesis suggests acute systolic heart failure. If left untreated, this can progress to cardiogenic shock and multiorgan dysfunction.
3. Coagulopathy: The patient has an elevated INR and PTT, indicating a coagulopathy. This increases the risk of bleeding complications. Monitoring of coagulation parameters and appropriate management is crucial.
4. Urinary tract infection (UTI): The presence of yeast in the urine suggests a UTI. If not treated promptly, it can lead to systemic infection and sepsis.
5. Anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, which may worsen over time. Monitoring of hemoglobin levels and appropriate management is necessary.

 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name **])
   Initial dyspnea likely due to influenza, patient now with increased
   pulmonary edema following aggressive volume resuscitation for sepsis.
   On repeat SBT today breathing became more labored so now back on AC.
   CXR shows persistent pulmonary edema. Patient needs continued diuresis,
   goal net negative 1-2 liters today. Will also aim for improved rate
   control, titrate metoprolol. Continue antibiotic coverage for now,
   follow up cultures. Holding vancomcyin today given elevated trough,
   would redose tomorrow for trough <20.
 SEPSIS, SEVERE (WITH ORGAN DYSFUNCTION)

   MAP>65, follow urine output.
 Influenza

   Day 3 of [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**] continue for 5 day course.

   Cr stable, making good amount s of urine. Follow for now.
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
   Patient on both diltiazem and metoprolol at home, neither of which at
   maximum dose, uncertain why patient on both of these. Increase
   metoprolol as above. Start heparin for anticoagulation for INR<2 today.
 DIABETES MELLITUS (DM), TYPE II
   Continue SQ insulin with fingersticks, glucose under fair control, goal
   fingersticks<150.
 URINARY TRACT INFECTION (UTI)
   Repeat UA with pyuria, only yeast isolated on recent cx, foley changed
   yesterday. Would not treat yeast in urine.
   Follow up repeat urine culture.
   h/o ESBL E. coli and Klebsiella [**3-2**] urine, should be covered by
   meropenem. s/p ~7 day course gentamicin.
 HEART FAILURE (CHF), DIASTOLIC, ACUTE ON CHRONIC
   EF depressed on TTE yesterday, suspect influenza related myocarditis.
   No evidence of new ischemic event as patient ruled out for MI by
   biomarkers. Can consider repeat TTE as outpatient to assess for
   recovery of pump function. Continue beta blockers, diuresis as above.
   Start captopril for afterload reduction, titrate up as BP tolerates.
 Coagulopathy
   Upon further history patient was indeed taking warfarin at home.
   Elevation may have been secondary to antibiotics vs nutrition. INR
   reversed successfully following vitamin K. Labs yesterday suggestive of
   possible low level DIC, will follow closely for evidence of bleeding.
 ANEMIA
   No evidence of active bleeding. Had normal iron studies [**2-8**], normal
   B12 and folate [**10-9**].
   Transfused yesterday per sepsis protocol to increase SVO2. Hct stable,
   no evidence of active bleeding. Transfuse Hb>7.
 Left shoulder dislocation, suspected
   Repeat shoulder imaging in [**3-6**] weeks to better assess per ortho recs
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: restart tube feeds, holding after midnight for ?extubation

The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of COPD, CAD, and CHF admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress. He was found to have influenza and is currently on mechanical ventilation. He has been diuresed, switched to pressure support ventilation, and given IV vitamin K due to being on Coumadin at home. The patient's allergies include Bactrim and Remeron. He is currently on multiple medications including heparin sodium, furosemide, meropenem, vancomycin, and propofol. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for the inability to answer pain questions. His vital signs show tachycardia and mild hypotension. The patient's physical examination reveals clear breath sounds, warm skin, and irregularly irregular tachyarrhythmia. Laboratory results indicate leukocytosis with a predominance of neutrophils, elevated troponin T, elevated D-dimer, and abnormal renal function tests. The patient's assessment includes respiratory failure, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, influenza, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus type II, urinary tract infection, acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, coagulopathy, anemia, and left shoulder dislocation. 1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to the combination of influenza-induced pneumonia and acute heart failure.

4. Pneumonia, Bacterial, Community Acquired (CAP): The patient has community-acquired bacterial pneumonia, which may have led to the development of sepsis.

5. Renal Failure, Acute (Acute Renal Failure, ARF): The patient has acute renal failure, possibly as a result of sepsis or dehydration.

6. Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): The patient has atrial fibrillation, which needs to be rate-controlled.

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and CAD. He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress due to influenza. He failed a spontaneous breathing test (SBT) and was placed back on assisted ventilation (AC). The patient has persistent candiduria, and a renal ultrasound showed an angiomyolipoma of the right kidney. Family meetings were held to discuss the patient's poor long-term prognosis, although he may recover from this acute illness. The patient has allergies to Bactrim and Risperidone, and his last dose of antibiotics was vancomycin on 03/25/2018 at 02:00 AM and meropenem on 03/26/2018 at 02:00 AM. Other medications include review of systems unchanged from admission except as noted below.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's initial dyspnea likely due to influenza has now progressed to acute respiratory failure, possibly secondary to pulmonary edema following aggressive volume resuscitation for sepsis. The patient is not yet ready for extubation, and ABG results show respiratory alkalosis. Continued diuresis is needed to manage pulmonary edema, and sedation may need to be increased.
2. Sepsis: The patient has severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, likely secondary to pneumonia. Antibiotics are being continued for an 8-day course, and vancomycin

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and CAD admitted to the ICU with respiratory distress due to influenza. The patient failed a spontaneous breathing trial and was placed back on assisted ventilation. A family meeting was held to discuss the patient's poor long-term prognosis, although he may pull through this acute illness. Renal ultrasound showed only an angiomyolipoma. The patient has allergies to Bactrim and Remeron. He received vancomycin and meropenem as antibiotics. 

Vital signs include a temperature of 37.2 C (98.9 F), heart rate of 113 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 105/56 mmHg to 170/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on ventilator support. The patient has atrial fibrillation. Fluid balance shows an intake of 1,478 mL and output of 3,720 mL. 

Respiratory support includes CPAP/PPS mode on the ventilator with set tidal volume of 400 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 13 cmH2O, and positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O. The patient's arterial blood gas values are pH 7.50, PaCO2 25 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio 287, and ventilation rate of 7.2 L/min. 

Physical examination reveals the patient to be thin, with clear breath sounds and paradoxical breathing. He has a tracheostomy tube in place. The patient's extremities are absent pulses on both sides. 

Laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 320 K/uL, elevated creatinine levels, and elevated lactate levels. The patient's coagulation profile indicates an INR of 1.5 and PTT of 150. Chest X-ray shows right upper lobe opacity, left-sided effusion, and decreased vascular markings. 

Assessment and plan include respiratory failure, severe sepsis, influenza, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus type II, urinary tract infection, heart failure, coagulopathy, and anemia. The patient's code status is do not resuscitate (DNR), and he is currently in the ICU.

Summary:
Based on the provided information, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and CAD. He was admitted with respiratory distress and influenza. The patient has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure, severe sepsis, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus type II, urinary tract infection, heart failure (both systolic and diastolic), coagulopathy, and chronic anemia.

The potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure due to the patient's underlying COPD and influenza infection. The presence of bilateral pleural effusion on the chest X-ray suggests possible fluid overload, which could indicate worsening heart failure or fluid management issues.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, and elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) levels, indicating an ongoing infection or inflammatory response.

The patient's medications include antibiotics (meropenem and vancomycin) for bacterial pneumonia and MRSA infection, antiviral medication (oseltamivir) for influenza, anticoagulants (heparin), and other supportive medications for various conditions.

Overall, the patient's condition requires close monitoring and management of respiratory support, fluid balance, antibiotic therapy, and treatment for other comorbidities.

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with respiratory distress admitted to the ICU. He has a history of chronic anemia, type II diabetes mellitus, atrial fibrillation, urinary tract infection, systolic and diastolic heart failure, and a recent influenza infection. The patient's current condition includes acute respiratory failure, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, bacterial pneumonia, acute renal failure, atrial fibrillation, and acute myocardial infarction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently experiencing acute respiratory failure due to influenza and Staphylococcus pneumonia. There is a risk of further respiratory complications if not managed appropriately.

2. Sepsis: The patient has had severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, indicating a systemic inflammatory response. This can lead to organ failure if not treated promptly and effectively.

3. Pneumonia: The patient has bacterial pneumonia, which may require continued antibiotic therapy and monitoring for any worsening respiratory symptoms.

4. Acute Renal Failure: The patient is showing signs of acute renal failure, which can be caused by severe sepsis, dehydration, or other factors. Close monitoring of renal function and appropriate management are necessary.

5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation, which may require anticoagulation therapy to prevent thromboembolic events. Management of this condition should involve rate control and consideration of rhythm control strategies.

6. Myocardial

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and CAD admitted for respiratory distress due to influenza B complicated by MRSA pneumonia. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation, with an RSBI of 50. The patient's blood pressure has been labile, dropping to the 50s after increasing Versed to 0.5 mg/hour, but improved with a 500cc bolus. The patient is also experiencing grimacing to verbal and physical stimuli, responds intermittently to commands, and has been biting and pulling at the endotracheal tube. The patient has allergies to Bactrim and Remeron, and is currently receiving midazolam (Versed), fentanyl, and heparin infusions.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to influenza B complicated by MRSA pneumonia. There is also evidence of volume overload from recent volume resuscitation and depressed EF. Moderate bilateral pleural effusions are seen on the CXR today.
2. Labile Blood Pressure: The patient has intermittent hypertension/hypotension, which is medication-sensitive and aggravated by agitation, contributing to vascular hyperresponsiveness.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's heart rate is not well-controlled between 100-130s due to BP lability in response to beta-blocker medication.
4. Diabetes Mellitus (DM), Type II: The patient has a history of DM and requires insulin sliding scale management.
5. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): Yeast is growing from cultures and urethral swab, indicating a UTI.
6. Heart Failure (CHF), Systolic, Acute: The patient has new systolic failure with an EF of 25-30%, likely related to influenza myocarditis or mild troponin leak in the setting of sepsis.
7. Coagulopathy: The patient was admitted with a supratherapeutic INR on Coumadin, which was corrected with Vit K.
8. Anemia: The patient has anemia likely due to chronic disease, with a current Hct of 26%. Daily monitoring and transfusion for Hct <21 is planned.
9. Shoulder Dislocation: An incidental finding of shoulder dislocation is noted on the CXR, and orthopedic management will be deferred until the patient is stable enough for better imaging.

Please note that this summary is based on the information provided in the progress note, and additional information or tests may be required for a comprehensive assessment.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of COPD, CHF, and CAD admitted for respiratory distress caused by influenza B complicated by MRSA pneumonia. The patient is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has moderate bilateral pleural effusions and a reduced ejection fraction of 25-30%. The patient's blood pressure is labile, requiring frequent adjustments in medication. He also has atrial fibrillation and is being started on digoxin for rate control. The patient has a urinary tract infection caused by yeast and is being treated with amphotericin. He also has type II diabetes mellitus and is on an insulin sliding scale. The patient has a history of systolic heart failure and is likely to improve with resolution of the infection. Coagulopathy is present due to supratherapeutic INR on Coumadin, which has been corrected with Vitamin K. Anemia is likely due to chronic disease. The patient has a dislocated shoulder, which will be managed after stabilization. He is receiving pain management through a g-tube with oxycodone.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure caused by influenza B and MRSA pneumonia. There is a risk of further respiratory failure if the infection spreads or if there are complications related to the mechanical ventilation.

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and congestive heart failure (CHF). The patient has had difficult ventilator interactions, with volatile blood pressure and agitation/delirium. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is acute and not associated with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Ventilatory support will be continued for now, with adjustments made as needed.

2. Sepsis: The patient has severe sepsis with organ dysfunction. Antibiotics, specifically vancomycin dosed by level for MRSA level, have been initiated and will be continued for a total of 10 days.

3. Renal failure: The patient had acute renal failure, which has since resolved.

4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and rate control measures will be implemented. Heparin has been started to prevent thromboembolic events.

5. Diabetes mellitus, type II: The patient has diabetes mellitus, which will require ongoing management and monitoring of blood glucose levels.

6. Urinary tract infection: The patient has a urinary tract infection, for which antibiotic treatment will be administered.

7. Heart failure: The patient has acute systolic heart failure, presumably related to influenza. Diuretics and afterload reduction will be continued. Captopril will be maintained at a low dose.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and congestive heart failure (CHF). The patient has multiple medical complications including anemia, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), severe sepsis (with organ dysfunction), bacterial community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), acute renal failure (ARF), atrial fibrillation (AFib), type II diabetes mellitus (DM), urinary tract infection (UTI), Clostridium difficile (C. Diff) infection, acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure (CHF), and acute-on-chronic diastolic heart failure (CHF). The patient also had a recent myocardial infarction (AMI).

The patient's vital signs show labile blood pressure, elevated heart rate, and slightly low respiratory rate. The oxygen saturation is within normal limits. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with controlled tidal volume, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP), and a low respiratory system resistance and compliance.

Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, elevated platelet count, normal electrolyte levels, and elevated D-dimer levels. Imaging shows persistent bilateral pleural effusions.

The patient's care plan includes continuing ventilatory support, decreasing minute ventilation due to respiratory alkalosis, continuing diuresis for CHF, treating sepsis with appropriate antibiotics, monitoring renal function, controlling AFib rate, managing diabetes, treating UTI, addressing C. Diff infection, managing CHF with afterload reduction and medication adjustments, and monitoring for complications related to recent AMI. The patient's ICU care includes nutrition support, glycemic control, line management, prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcers, and elevation of head of bed (HOB) to prevent ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, progression of sepsis with organ dysfunction, exacerbation of heart failure, development of kidney injury, uncontrolled atrial fibrillation, worsening diabetes control, progression of urinary tract infection, recurrence of C. Diff infection, and potential complications related to recent myocardial infarction.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently admitted to the ICU with multiple medical complications. These include respiratory failure, acute atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressures, acute systolic heart failure, urinary tract infection, type II diabetes mellitus, and chronic diastolic heart failure. 

The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial and includes influenza A complicated by MRSA pneumonia and volume overload. The patient has been intubated and ventilated on assist-control mode with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a respiratory system resistance of 78. The arterial blood gas (ABG) shows an improved pH of 7.46 and CO2 of 38, indicating better ventilation. However, the patient remains somnolent and minimally responsive to commands, suggesting that they may not be able to tolerate extubation.

   & minimally responsive to commands this am, likely not able to tolerate
   extubation.  Complete 5/5 days oseltamivir

The patient's renal function is impaired with an elevated creatinine level. The liver function tests are within normal limits, but the patient has elevated lactate levels.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is critically ill and admitted to the ICU due to respiratory failure. The patient has a history of chronic conditions including atrial fibrillation, chronic anemia, diabetes mellitus type II, heart failure (both systolic and diastolic), and a possible myocardial infarction. The patient also has an active infection with pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and a yeast infection in the bladder. 

The patient's vital signs show tachycardia, low blood pressure, and an irregular heart rhythm. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with pressure support, and there are concerns about weaning the patient off the ventilator due to delirium. 

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count and D-dimer levels, as well as abnormal kidney function. Imaging shows blunting of the right greater than left costophrenic angles, indicating possible pleural effusions. 

The patient's plan includes advancing the endotracheal tube, discussing a tracheostomy with the family, continuing anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation, transfusing for anemia, treating the infections, managing heart failure, and providing glycemic control. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Difficult wean from mechanical ventilation due to delirium.
2. Pleural effusions.
3. Chronic anemia requiring transfusion.
4. Infections (pneumonia, urinary tract infection, yeast infection).
5. Heart failure (both systolic

Summary:
Summary of the Progress Note:

The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), and congestive heart failure (CHF). The patient has volatile blood pressure, agitation, and delirium, making it difficult to wean off the ventilator. The patient's medical history includes atrial fibrillation, chronic anemia, diabetes mellitus type II, urinary tract infection (UTI), acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, and a suspected acute myocardial infarction.

The patient is currently on various medications including metoprolol, digoxin, diuretics, and antibiotics for VAP. The patient's vital signs show tachycardia, hypotension, and an elevated respiratory rate. The patient's oxygen saturation is within normal limits. The patient's laboratory results indicate abnormalities in electrolyte levels, kidney function, liver enzymes, and cardiac markers.

Imaging shows persistent blunting of right greater than left costophrenic angles, with an elevated endotracheal tube and other lines appearing okay. The patient's nutritional support includes tube feeds. The plan includes attempting to wean pressure support, advancing the endotracheal tube, discussing tracheostomy, and managing the patient's conditions such as atrial fibrillation, anemia, diabetes, UTI, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Difficult wean

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is an 85-year-old man who was admitted with respiratory failure due to sepsis from MRSA pneumonia. He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and labile blood pressure and heart rate, which is thought to be due to agitation and sensitivity to medications. The patient also has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure and was found to have a globally depressed ejection fraction of 25-30% on admission, possibly related to viral myocarditis or sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy. No regional wall motion abnormalities were seen.

The patient has been aggressively volume resuscitated with a depressed ejection fraction and continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions and pulmonary edema. He is able to tolerate minimal ventilator support for 3-4 hours at a time, but then develops tachypnea and alkalosis of unknown etiology. It is unclear if this is due to agitation or severely decompensated respiratory status and poor baseline functioning. The patient is not likely to be extubated today, and a plan for a family meeting with the attending regarding possible tracheostomy has been made.

The patient is receiving Vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia and will recheck arterial blood gas (ABG) this morning. The respiratory therapists are working on addressing the patient's tachypnea and alkalosis. The patient received 1

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), congestive heart failure (CHF), and agitation. The patient's respiratory failure is complicated by delirium, making him a poor candidate for extubation.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 100.6Â°F
- Heart rate: 93 bpm
- Blood pressure: 118/64 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 30 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 99%
- Atrial fibrillation (irregular heart rhythm)

The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 35%. The respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) is 63.

The patient has a history of chronic anemia, type II diabetes mellitus, urinary tract infection (UTI) caused by yeast, acute-on-chronic diastolic heart failure, and a possible acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The patient also has delirium and chronic Clostridium difficile infection.

The patient's laboratory results show:
- Hemoglobin: 10.8 g/dL
- White blood cell count: 9.4 K/uL
- Platelet count: 390 K/uL

- Potassium: 4.3 mEq/L
- Chloride: 103 mEq/L
- Calcium: 8.3 mg/dL
- Magnesium: 1.9 mg/dL
- Phosphate: 2.8 mg/dL

The patient's imaging shows an endotracheal tube at 3 cm above the carina, right internal jugular (IJ) line in good position, and bilateral pleural effusions layering, rotated.

The plan includes discussing tracheostomy with the family due to the patient's slow progress, mental status, secretion, and weakness contributing to poor weaning. Efforts will be made to diurese the effusions. The patient's atrial fibrillation is being anticoagulated with heparin, and blood pressures and rates seem better controlled. The patient's chronic anemia will be monitored. The patient's antibiotics for community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) will be completed today. The patient's type II diabetes will continue to be managed. The urinary tract infection will be rechecked with a urinalysis. The patient's heart failure will be monitored with a goal fluid balance of -500 mL per day, and low-dose captopril will be continued. The patient has diminished breath sounds throughout, and there are no rhonchi. Cardiovascular examination shows an irregular heartbeat with no murmurs. Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 85-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure due to sepsis from MRSA pneumonia. The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure and was found to have a globally depressed ejection fraction of 25-30%. The patient also has chronic atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure and heart rate, which is thought to be due to agitation and extreme sensitivity to medications. 

The patient's current condition includes moderate bilateral pleural effusions and pulmonary edema. He is able to tolerate minimal ventilator support for 3-4 hours at a time but develops tachypnea and alkalosis of unknown etiology. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.2Â°C (98.9Â°F), a heart rate of 111 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 115/94 to 100/44 mmHg, respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation.

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 13.0 K/uL, an elevated lactate level of 1.1 mmol/L, and elevated D-dimer levels. Other lab results indicate hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia.

The patient's plan includes continuing vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia, rechecking

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male admitted with respiratory failure and sepsis due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia. He has been aggressively volume resuscitated but continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions and pulmonary edema. The patient also has atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure and heart failure with a depressed ejection fraction (EF) of 25-30%. He is currently on various medications including vancomycin, digoxin, metoprolol, heparin, and others. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status remains unstable, and there is a concern for ongoing respiratory failure. Continuous monitoring and support with mechanical ventilation may be required.

2. Sepsis: Although the patient has completed a course of vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia, he remains at risk for sepsis due to other potential sources of infection. Close monitoring of vital signs, laboratory parameters, and cultures will be necessary to detect any signs of recurrent or new infections.

3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure, which can lead to hemodynamic instability. It is important to optimize rate control and anticoagulation therapy to prevent thromboembolic events.

4. Heart Failure: The patient's depressed EF indicates significant impairment of left ventricular function, placing him at risk for worsening heart failure

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 85-year-old male admitted with respiratory failure, possibly secondary to sepsis from MRSA pneumonia. He has been aggressively volume resuscitated but continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions and pulmonary edema. The patient is able to tolerate minimal ventilator support for a few hours before developing tachypnea and alkalosis of unknown etiology. It is unclear if this is due to agitation or severely decompensated respiratory status and poor baseline functioning. The patient is not likely to be extubated today, and a plan for a family meeting with Attg regarding possible tracheostomy placement has been made.

The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure and heart rate, which is thought to be due to agitation and extreme sensitivity to medications. He has been started on digoxin and increased beta-blocker overnight to achieve better rate control. He is currently on metoprolol 100mg TID and digoxin 0.125mg IV daily, and his digoxin level will be checked.

The patient also has heart failure with a depressed ejection fraction of 25-30% on admission, possibly related to viral myocarditis or sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy. No regional wall motion abnormalities were seen, and his cardiac function is expected to recover in 6-8 weeks. Follow-up echocardiogram is needed. The patient's chest X-ray shows

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, VAP, CHF, agitation, and delirium. He remains a very poor extubation candidate given his RSBI, extreme weakness, poor mental status/agitation, and secretions, volume overload/CHF, and fatigue. He has been intubated for 9 days and will continue discussion with the family regarding tracheostomy as it is felt that he will have a prolonged ventilator wean. Ethics consultation will be involved in the decision-making process.

The patient's current assessment and plan include:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains very poor for extubation due to various factors. The plan is to continue discussion with the family regarding tracheostomy, as it is believed that the patient will require prolonged ventilator support. Ethics consultation will assist in the decision-making process.
2. CHF: The patient has acute systolic heart failure, likely related to influenza and post-viral myocarditis. The plan is to continue monitoring fluid balance with a goal of -500 mL/day (generally lasix) and continue low-dose captopril.
3. Diastolic Heart Failure: The patient has chronic diastolic heart failure. Rate control measures will be continued as before.
4. Anemia: The patient's chronic anemia continues to drift down due to chronic illness and blood draws. Monitoring is recommended.
5. Bacterial Pneumonia

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), congestive heart failure (CHF), agitation, and delirium. He remains very poor extubation candidate given his low respiratory system compliance index (RSBI), extreme weakness, poor mental status/agitation, and secretions and volume overload/CHF. He has been intubated for 9 days and will likely require a prolonged ventilator wean. Tracheostomy will be discussed with the family as a possible option. The patient's atrial fibrillation (AFIB) is being managed with increased metoprolol dose/digoxin. He is anticoagulated with heparin due to bloody pulmonary secretions. His heart failure, both systolic and diastolic, is being treated accordingly. He also has chronic anemia, type II diabetes mellitus, urinary tract infection (UTI), and a history of myocardial infarction. Delirium, chronic C. difficile infection, hypothyroidism, and other issues are also being addressed. The patient's current medications and treatments include diuretics for effusions and CHF, midazolam infusion, olanzapine, and others. The patient's condition is critical, and ongoing discussions are being held with the family regarding goals of care, including ethics involvement.

   .

   BPs/HR thought due to agitation and extreme sensitivity to

   .

   depressed EF of 25-30% on admission, possible related to viral
   myocarditis vs sepsis induced CMP.  No RWMA, function likely to recover
   in 6-8wks, will need follow up echo.  Diuresed well overnight, CXR

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 85-year-old man admitted with respiratory failure due to sepsis from MRSA pneumonia. He was aggressively volume resuscitated with a depressed ejection fraction and continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions and pulmonary edema. The patient's work of breathing (WOB) is increased, and he is experiencing tachypnea and respiratory alkalosis. The respiratory system compliance (RSBI) is 115, indicating that extubation is not likely to be tolerated. The family is being consulted regarding the possibility of tracheostomy placement.

The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure and heart rate, which is thought to be due to agitation and extreme sensitivity to medications. Digoxin and metoprolol have been started for rate control, and heparin is being administered for anticoagulation.

The patient also has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure, and a depressed ejection fraction of 25-30% was noted on admission. This may be related to viral myocarditis or sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy. Diuretics are being used for volume overload, and follow-up echocardiogram is planned.

The patient's urine cultures were positive for yeast, and he has completed three days of amphotericin B therapy. Repeat urine analysis shows no yeast present.

The patient has a diagnosis of type II diabetes mellitus and chronic disease-related anemia. His

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old man admitted with respiratory failure and sepsis from methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia. The patient has been aggressively volume resuscitated due to depressed left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions. The patient's chest X-ray shows mildly improved pulmonary vascular congestion.

The patient did not tolerate pressure support with respiratory alkalosis and was maintained on assisted ventilation overnight. The respiratory system compliance index (RSBI) is 115, indicating that the patient is not likely to tolerate extubation. Ongoing family meetings are being held with the attending physician regarding the possibility of tracheostomy placement and code status.

The patient has completed a course of Vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia, currently on day 11. The patient diuresed well overnight and appears contracted on morning labs, aiming for a net input/output balance. Supportive care is being provided, and planning for possible tracheostomy placement has been consulted with the ethics committee.

The patient has low-grade fevers and atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure. The patient's chronic atrial fibrillation is better controlled on Digoxin and Metoprolol 100mg TID. Rate control is still being worked on, ranging from 90-120 beats per minute currently. Heparin is being continued for anticoagulation,

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old man admitted with respiratory failure due to sepsis from methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia. He has been intubated for 9 days and is at high risk for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient also has atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure, heart failure with a depressed ejection fraction, and a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and diastolic congestive heart failure. Additionally, the patient has a urinary tract infection caused by yeast, diabetes mellitus type II, anemia, and a coagulopathy with a supratherapeutic INR. The patient also has a left shoulder dislocation, which will be managed after he is medically stable.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, development of VAP, worsening heart failure, worsening atrial fibrillation, worsening anemia, worsening coagulopathy, and worsening diabetes control.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, oxygen saturation levels, respiratory status, fluid balance, and laboratory values to detect any potential complications early on and intervene promptly.

The patient has been aggressively volume resuscitated due to depressed left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions and pulmonary edema. His current vital signs include a temperature of 38.3Â°C, heart rate of 105 bpm, blood pressure of 119/72 mmHg, respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. His laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, platelet count, and several abnormal values in electrolytes and kidney function tests. The patient has a history of left shoulder dislocation, which will be managed after he is medically stable. 

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's current condition indicates ongoing respiratory failure due to multifactorial etiology, including influenza and secondary MRSA pneumonia. There is a possibility of worsening respiratory status leading to further respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient has already experienced sepsis from MRSA pneumonia, and there is a risk of developing sepsis

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male with a complex medical history who is currently admitted to the ICU. The patient has multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type II, chronic heart failure (both systolic and diastolic), chronic anemia, community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), urinary tract infection (UTI), and a history of myocardial infarction.

The patient's current condition is critical, with ongoing respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), congestive heart failure (CHF), agitation, and delirium. The patient has been intubated for 10 days and requires ongoing mechanical ventilation support.

The patient's vital signs are unstable, with an elevated temperature, tachycardia, and hypertension. The patient's blood gases show respiratory acidosis with hypoxemia and hypercapnia. The patient's laboratory results indicate leukocytosis and elevated inflammatory markers.

The patient has several potential medical complications that need to be addressed. These include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient remains a poor candidate for extubation due to an elevated respiratory system resistance index (RSBI), extreme weakness, poor mental status, secretions, volume overload/CHF, and fatigue. The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored, and a discussion regarding tracheostomy placement should be considered.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), congestive heart failure (CHF), agitation, and delirium. The patient has been unable to be weaned from the ventilator. 

24-hour events include the insertion of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) line and removal of a presep catheter. The patient had a temperature of 100.9 degrees Fahrenheit and was not extubated. 

The patient has allergies to Bactrim and Remeron. The last dose of antibiotics was vancomycin on 03/30/2018 at 1:43 PM. The patient is receiving midazolam and heparin infusions, as well as other ICU medications.

Vital signs include a maximum temperature of 38.3 degrees Celsius, current temperature of 37.4 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 104 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 106/65 to 136/76 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is in atrial fibrillation and has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 15 mmHg.

Fluid balance shows a total intake of 1,848 mL, including 852 mL of IV fluids, 1,090 mL of tube feedings, and 518 mL of oral intake. Total output includes 1,865 mL of urine, 190 mL of blood products, and 662 mL of drain output. The fluid balance is -17 mL.

Respiratory support consists of mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate set at 15 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%, and spontaneous respiratory rate of 7 breaths per minute.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count ranging from 11.9 to 13.9 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.9 g/dL, platelet count ranging from 437 to 498 K/uL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 25 mg/dL, creatinine of 0.6 mg/dL, and glucose levels ranging from 128 to 145 mg/dL. Other lab results include elevated D-dimer levels and low fibrinogen levels.

Imaging shows slightly improved vascular congestion and pleural effusions bilaterally. Microbiology results indicate a negative urine culture.

Assessment and Plan:
The main issues remaining include respiratory failure, acute on chronic CHF, agitation, delirium, and failure to wean from the ventilator. The patient has low-grade temperatures and leukocytosis, suggesting a new infection. The plan includes continuing antibiotic therapy, checking head and chest CT scans, and repeating blood, urine, and sputum cultures.

The patient also has atrial fibrillation, for which anticoagulation and rate control medications are being used. The patient has acute systolic heart failure due to presumed influenza and post-viral myocarditis. Diurese is being held, and low-dose captopril is being continued for afterload reduction.

The patient has chronic anemia and chronic diastolic heart failure. Myocardial infarction is likely secondary to demand ischemia in the setting of sepsis. Aspirin and Plavix are being continued, along with beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors.

Delirium has improved with the use of olanzapine and minimal versed. Chronic Clostridium difficile infection is being treated with vancomycin. Other issues discussed with the house staff, with whose assessments and plans I agree. 

ICU care includes nutrition support with a pulmonary formula and glycemic control with regular insulin sliding scale. Prophylactic measures include systemic anticoagulation and stress ulcer prophylaxis.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male admitted with respiratory failure due to sepsis from MRSA pneumonia. He has been aggressively volume resuscitated with a depressed ejection fraction and continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions. The patient has continued respiratory alkalosis and was maintained on assisted ventilation overnight. He is sedated and not responding to commands this morning after receiving a fentanyl bolus. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is intubated for 10 days and has low-grade fevers and an elevated white blood cell count, which raises concern for VAP. Blood and urine cultures are pending, and the patient is being started on empiric antibiotics with Vancomycin and Piperacillin/Tazobactam.

2. Sinus infection: The patient has increased bloody secretions, and a head CT is ordered to rule out a sinus infection.

3. Atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure: The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation and labile blood pressures that have been better controlled on digoxin and metoprolol. Rate control is still being worked on, ranging from 90-120 beats per minute currently.

4. Heart failure: The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure and was found to have a globally depressed ejection fraction of 25-30% on admission. This could be related to viral myocarditis or sepsis-induced

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), congestive heart failure (CHF), agitation, and delirium. He has been unable to be weaned from the ventilator. The patient has a history of chronic illnesses, including hypothyroidism and possible post-polio syndrome. He has had multiple infections and is currently on treatment for Clostridium difficile (C. diff). There are concerns about new infections, as indicated by low-grade fever and increasing white blood cell count (WBC). Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), congestive heart failure (CHF), agitation, and delirium. The main issues remaining are respiratory failure, acute on chronic CHF, and probable VAP/infection. The patient remains a very poor extubation candidate and has been intubated for 11 days. There is concern for a new infection, as indicated by low-grade temperatures and increasing white blood cell count. 

The patient's atrial fibrillation (AFIB) is better controlled with increased metoprolol dose/digoxin, but the patient is still tachycardic. Anticoagulation with heparin has been stopped due to ongoing bloody oral secretions. 

The patient has acute systolic heart failure, presumptively related to influenza and post-viral myocarditis. Monitoring fluid balance and holding on diuretics is recommended. 

The patient also has chronic diastolic heart failure, with previous diagnosis. Rate control as mentioned above is advised. 

Chronic anemia continues to drift down/chronic illness, and blood draws on heparin will be discontinued. 

There is a suspicion of an acute myocardial infarction (AMI), likely demand ischemia in the setting of sepsis. ASA and Plavix should be continued, along with beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors.

   85 y/o man admitted with respiratory failure [**3-5**] to sepsis from MRSA
   PNA now with Klebsiella VAP.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Etiology multifactorial, pt was admitted with
   Influenza c/b secondary MRSA PNA.  s/p aggressive volume resuscitation
   with depressed EF, pt continues to have moderate bilateral pleural
   effusions. Pt with ongoing resp alkalosis and was maintained on AC
   overnight. Increased sedation this am to [**Month (only) 38**] overbreathing vent. Pt not
   likely to tolerate extubation (NIFF -1, last RSBI 84). Ongoing
   discussions with family regarding trach placement.
   - completed 10 day course of Vancomycin for MRSA PNA
   - concern for VAP given low grade temps & elev WBC, now day [**4-8**]
   Vanc/Zosyn
   - supportive care, planning for possible trach placement, consulted
   ethics
   .
   # ID: Low grade fevers & rising WBC count concerning for VAP in pt
   intubated for 10 days.
   - blood & urine Cx NGTD
   - trach sputum cultures + Klebsiella, will continue Vanc/Zosyn
   - hct trended down & increased bloody secretions, concern for sinus
   infection
   - Head CT to r/o sinus infection- c/w sinusisitis v mastoiditis
   - will call ENT to see if sinus worth tapping, if not, can peel off
   vanc
   - Chest CT possible RLL PNA
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation with Labile BP: Pt with chronic A.Fib and labile
   BPs that have been better controlled on Digoxin & Metoprolol 100mg
   TID.  Now bradycardic, with SBPs<100.
   - continue Metoprolol 100mg TID; d/c Diltiazem
   - continue Digoxin 0.125mg IV daily
   - due to hct drop & ongoing bloody secretions from oropharynx, will d/c
   heparin today (daily risk of CVA in pt with A. Fib very low)
   .
   # HEART FAILURE: Pt with h/o diastolic CHF, found to have globally
   depressed EF of 25-30% on admission, possible related to viral
   myocarditis vs sepsis induced CMP.  No RWMA, function likely to recover
   in 6-8wks, will need follow up echo.
   - continue Captopril 6.25mg q6hr for afterload reduction
   .
   # UTI: Urine cultures form [**3-27**] + for yeast, now completed 3 days of
   Amphotericin CBI.  Repeat UAs +leuks & >100 WBCs, no yeast.  Will
   change out foley today
   - Urine culture NGTD

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male admitted with respiratory failure secondary to sepsis from MRSA pneumonia, now with Klebsiella ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient has ongoing respiratory alkalosis and was maintained on assisted ventilation overnight. He is not likely to tolerate extubation, with a NIF score of 1 and last respiratory support burden index (RSBI) of 84. There are ongoing discussions with the family regarding possible tracheostomy placement.

The patient completed a 10-day course of vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia but has low-grade fevers and rising white blood cell count, which is concerning for VAP. Blood and urine cultures have been sent, and tracheostomy sputum cultures grew Klebsiella, so the patient will continue on vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam.

The patient's hemoglobin concentration has trended down, and there are increased bloody secretions, raising concern for sinus infection. A head CT has been ordered to rule out sinus infection, which could be related to sinusitis and/or mastoiditis. ENT consultation will be sought to determine if the sinus is worth tapping.

A chest CT showed possible right lower lobe pneumonia. The patient has chronic atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure, better controlled on digoxin and metoprolol 100mg TID. However, the patient is now bradycardic with systolic blood pressures

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), congestive heart failure (CHF), agitation, and delirium. He has a history of chronic illness and is currently on day 12 of intubation. The patient has been diagnosed with klebsiella pneumonia and sinusitis. He is receiving treatment for hypothyroidism and has a previous diagnosis of diastolic heart failure. The patient is also being treated for C. difficile and has a history of post-polio syndrome. His current condition includes respiratory failure, anemia, atrial fibrillation, acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure, delirium, and chronic C. difficile.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is due to a combination of pleural effusions, CHF, and probable VAP/infection. This makes him a poor candidate for extubation.
2. Nosocomial infection: The patient has developed a new nosocomial infection, specifically klebsiella pneumonia, which is resistant to antibiotics.
3. Heart failure: The patient has acute-on-chronic systolic heart failure and diastolic heart failure. These conditions can worsen and lead to further complications if not managed properly.
4. Delirium: The patient is experiencing delirium, which can be associated with infections, medications, or other underlying medical

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old male with a history of influenza, NSTEMI, CHF, respiratory failure, and failure to wean. He is currently experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure due to influenza, VAP, CHF, agitation, delirium, and a new nosocomial infection, probable sinusitis, and klebsiella pneumonia. The patient has been intubated for 12 days and is a poor candidate for extubation. There is ongoing discussion about performing a tracheostomy to facilitate weaning from mechanical ventilation. 

The patient has multiple medical complications, including respiratory failure, acute kidney injury, anemia, atrial fibrillation, acute on chronic diastolic heart failure, and a possible myocardial infarction. He also has chronic diarrhea and delirium. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis, low-grade fever, elevated D-dimer, and elevated troponin levels. Imaging studies reveal a probable right lower lobe pneumonia, bilateral pleural effusions, and signs of chronic illness. 

The patient's treatment plan includes ongoing antibiotic therapy for klebsiella pneumonia, continuation of C. difficile treatment, and close monitoring of fluid balance and electrolytes. The patient is on a combination of medications for heart failure, including low-dose captopril for afterload reduction, beta-blockers for rate control, and aspirin and Plavix for antiplatelet therapy. Olanzapine is

   85 y/o man admitted with respiratory failure [**3-5**] to sepsis from MRSA
   PNA now with Klebsiella VAP.
   .
   # RESPIRATORY FAILURE: Etiology multifactorial, pt was admitted with
   Influenza c/b secondary MRSA PNA. Aggressively volume resussitated with
   depressed EF & continued bilateral pulm effusions. Pt developped low
   grade temps s/p 10 days of  Vanc & sputum was +klebsiella.  Pt now day
   [**5-9**] Vanc/Zosyn for VAP. Pt not likely to tolerate extubation (NIFF -1,
   last RSBI 84). Ongoing discussions with family regarding trach
   placement.
   - completed 10 day course of Vancomycin for MRSA PNA
   - day [**5-9**] Zosyn for VAP (klebsiella [**Last Name (un) **] to zosyn)
   - supportive care, planning for possible trach placement, consulted
   ethics
   .
   # ID: Low grade fevers & rising WBC count likely c/w VAP in pt
   intubated for 12 days.
   - blood & urine Cx NGTD
   - trach sputum cultures + Klebsiella sensitive to Zosyn
   - hct trended down & increased bloody oropharyngeal secretions, will
   consult ENT today
   - Head CT c/w sinusisitis vs mastoiditis
   - Chest CT showed possible RLL PNA
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation with Labile BP: Pt with chronic A.Fib and labile
   BPs that have been better controlled on Digoxin & Metoprolol 100mg
   TID.  Pt had an episode of bradycardia on [**2185-4-3**] and Diltiazem was
   d/c
d. HR stable today in 80s
   - continue Metoprolol 100mg TID
   - continue Digoxin 0.125mg IV daily
   - d/c plavix, continue low dose ASA 81mg (will touch base with outpt
   cardiologist tonight)
   - holding anticoagulation, hct drop with ongoing bloody secretions from
   oropharynx
    (daily risk of CVA in pt with A. Fib very low)
   .
   # HEART FAILURE: Pt with h/o diastolic CHF, found to have globally
   depressed EF of 25-30% on admission, possible related to viral
   myocarditis vs sepsis induced CMP.  No RWMA, function likely to recover
   in 6-8wks, will need follow up echo.
   - continue Captopril 6.25mg q6hr for afterload reduction
   .
   # UTI: Urine cultures form [**3-27**] + for yeast, now completed 3 days of
   Amphotericin CBI.  Repeat UAs +leuks & >100 WBCs, no yeast.  Foley
   changed out [**4-2**]
   - Urine cultures NGTD
   # DM TYPEII: continue ISS with TF
   # ANEMIA: etiology likely [**3-5**] chronic disease, blood loss from
   oropharynx?.  Transfused 1 upRBCs overnight & went from 23.5 to 25.
   Will recheck pm hct
   -stools guaiac negative
   # C. Diff: pt with h/o relapsing/recurrent c.diff on a slow taper as
   outpt.  Curbsided ID today, will increase to treatment dose po
   Vancomycin 125mg q6hr while on Zosyn & resume taper post Abx.
   # Left shoulder dislocation: incidentally seen on CXR, per ortho,
   deferring management until medically stable to tolerate MRI.
   - fentanyl prn pain/agitation

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is an 85-year-old man admitted with respiratory failure and sepsis from MRSA pneumonia. He now has Klebsiella ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and has completed a 10-day course of Vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia. The patient is intubated for 12 days and has low-grade fevers and rising white blood cell count, likely indicating VAP. Blood and urine cultures are pending.

The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure, which has been better controlled on Digoxin and Metoprolol. The patient experienced an episode of bradycardia, and Diltiazem was discontinued. The heart rate is stable in the 80s.

The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure and globally depressed ejection fraction of 25-30% on admission. The function is expected to recover in 6-8 weeks, and a follow-up echo will be needed.

The patient's urine cultures initially grew yeast, but after completing 3 days of Amphotericin B, the repeat urine analysis showed no yeast. Foley catheter was changed.

The patient has chronic anemia likely due to chronic disease, with blood loss from the oropharynx. He received 1 unit of packed red blood cells overnight and his hemoglobin concentration increased from 23

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 85-year-old male admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure, suspected to be caused by sepsis due to methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia. The patient has now developed ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) caused by Klebsiella.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, with initial admission related to influenza and subsequent MRSA pneumonia. Despite aggressive volume resuscitation, the patient continues to have moderate bilateral pleural effusions. The patient is also experiencing respiratory alkalosis and requires ongoing mechanical ventilation support.
2. Infection: The patient has completed a 10-day course of vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia. There are concerns for VAP given low-grade fevers and an elevated white blood cell count. Blood and urine cultures are pending, and the patient is currently on vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn).
3. Anemia: The patient has anemia likely due to chronic disease and possible blood loss from the oropharynx. A transfusion of 1 unit of packed red blood cells was given overnight, resulting in an increase in hematocrit from 23.5% to 25%.
4. UTI: The patient initially had a urine culture positive for yeast, but subsequent urinalysis showed no yeast, indicating resolution of the urinary tract

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is an 85-year-old man admitted with respiratory failure, sepsis from MRSA pneumonia, and now with Klebsiella ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
- The patient has ongoing respiratory alkalosis and was maintained on assisted ventilation overnight. Increased sedation this morning due to overbreathing on the ventilator.
- The patient is not likely to tolerate extubation (NIFF -1, last Respiratory System Biochemical Index (RSBI) 84). Ongoing discussions with the family regarding tracheostomy placement.
- The patient completed a 10-day course of Vancomycin for MRSA pneumonia.
- There are concerns for VAP given low-grade fevers and elevated white blood cell count.
- Blood and urine cultures are pending.
- The patient has a trend of decreasing hematocrit and increased bloody secretions, which may indicate a sinus infection.
- A head CT was ordered to rule out sinus infection, consistent with sinusitis or mastoiditis.
- The patient's atrial fibrillation with labile blood pressure is being managed with metoprolol and digoxin.
- Heparin was held due to the patient's drop in hemoglobin and ongoing bloody secretions from the oropharynx.
- The patient has a history of diastolic congestive heart failure and a depressed ejection fraction on admission, possibly related to viral myocarditis or sepsis-induced cardiomyopathy.
-

The patient's current vital signs include a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, blood pressure of 121/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient has pleural effusions, CHF, and probable VAP/infection, with significant weakness being the main issue with weaning. The patient is now on day 13 of intubation and remains very poor for extubation.
